For the first time in the history
of the Johns Hopkins University a
near total eclipse will take place,
yet no attempt will be made by
the University to study this occurrence, according to the Geology
and Physics Departments. As the
University has no astronomical
department the Physics Department has carried on any work of
this nature in past years. When
the University moved to Homewood all the apparatus was left
stored in the old buildings. No
men will be sent north to witness
the total eclipse as Dean Ames
and Dr. Bliss say there is no scientific value to be derived from
Witnessing them other than that
which has already been obtained.

Contrary to custom, the 1925
"Hullabaloo" will not post its
group pictures for public inspection; it was decided at the last
board meeting, January 19. At the
same meeting a committee was
appointed for the purpose of taking separate, photographs of
seniors when each was in his favorite mood.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 23. 1925

Stanley Worden
Stars with
Playshop in
La liaison Natale
This is a difficult situation. We
want to
praise
highly the acting
and staging of the
Homewood Playshoppers' latest
production and yet we wish to
criticize the play itself. So in starting let us announce that we thoroughly enjoyed the aforesaid acting and staging. We only want to
bring out some weak spots in the
work of the Playshoppers wherever
We noticed them.
Jacques Copeau, Director, Le
Theatre du Vieux Colombier, Paris,
was associated many years with little theatres and their ideas before
he wrote La Maison Natale (The
Home into Which We Are Born),
yet this play hardly seems the type
best suited for little theatre actors.
The Homewood Playshop presented
it January 15, 16, 17, 20 and 21,
Which was the first time the production as translated by Ralph Roeder
was given in this country.
As best as we could discern the
action of the play seemed to revolve about a shrewd human—he
dies in the second intermission—
who .had underhandedly forced the
mayor of a small town to give him
his (laughter in marriage and his
factory, only to have his own children fear him and avoid his presence. The children especially the
Youngest son, prefer their now
broken old grandfather. This old
rascal, desiring revenge on his sonin-law, influences them to run away
from their father's oppression in
order to escape the fate of their
mother, and himself who have
cracked under the strain.
The acting of Stanley Worden
as the grandfather far surpassed
that of the rest. Mr. Worden is
still the most valuable man the
Playshoppers possess 'andlikewise
is the only one who retains his
character, whatever it may be, during the curtain calls.
The play itself seemed to us to
Portray its principal idea fairly
Well, though a bit morbidly: yet it
lacked a certain ease in the conversational speeches, many of which
were very long. This smoothness
may have been lost in the translat-

ing, which was evidently no masterpiece. The Playshoppers should
vary their type of plays a little
more and give lowbrows like ourselves a chance once in a while.
We did not think John Taylor
Myers quite lived up to his reputation of having once been in The
Miracle when he portrayed the
character of Andre, the idealistic
son. However we must admit his
was the most difficult role in the
performance.
G. H. Pouder in the part of the
harsh father evidently liked Clayton Hamilton's description of John
Barrymore's acting with his fingers
and eyebrows, for to our mind he
slightly overworked these parts of
his anatomy in giving vent to his
feelings. Mr. Pouder also seemed
to lose the value of a few lines and
often made his speeches while looking directly at the audience. Al-

though these lines may have had self contained possibilities with bet-- production was worthy of a much

ART PRINTS AND
Painters, authors, and musicians win
fame and fortune by transmitting their
conceptions to paper. Achievement
can be completed merely with such
expression of an idea. Not so with
engineering. The design of a turbine
or of a flat iron, once it is created, is
not placed upon a pedestal in a millionaire's mansion,or in an art museum.
It immediately goes into the shop-there to be executed. Its success is
measured by the degree to which it
fits manufacturing requirements. If it
can't be manufactured economically

REGISTAR GIVES
CONSOLING FIGURES

it is a failure.

With examinations .only
some seventy hours distant
from the time this issue is
placed in the post office
boxes in the dim basement
of Gilman Hall, certain figures from the Registrar's Office come as a great comfort.

In an organization like Westinghouse there is a group of engineers
whose chief interest and concern is
the efficient, economical, large scale
manufacture of electrical products.
These men may be electrical engineers

Mr. Dempster announces,
with a click of his jaws, that
there are at present fortyeight on the blacklist, twenty-two of whom are on probation. As next week will
offer the large Freshman
class its first introduction to
this dubious honor roll, that
click seems to foretell an increase. Just as a ray of sunshine the Registrar points
out in parting that only
fifty-six out of every hundred
entering reach the rank of
Juniors..

or mechanical engineers. They are
primarily interested in shop practice
and methods—.--in the same industrial
problems as are the manufacturing
customers whom Westinghouse serves.
The founder of Westinghouse was
such an engineer. He possessed a marvelous faculty to inspire workmen and
executives alike; there are many tales
of men working nights and Sundays to
help him complete a cherished plan.
Throughout all industry there is a
call for men qualified as manufacturing
engineers who can combine materials,
machines, men, and methods with
better and more efficient results.
Such men find pleasure and inspiration at Westinghouse — developing
apparatus to help other manufacturing
executives solve similar problems in
every kind of industry.

This advertisement is fifth in a vocational series, outlining the fields
for engineering achievement in the Westinghouse organization.

For the first time in the history
of the Johns Hopkins University a
near total eclipse will take place,
yet no attempt will be made by
the University to study this occurrence, according to the Geology
and Physics Departments. As the
University has no astronomical
department the Physics Department has carried on any work of
this nature in past years. When
the University moved to Homewood all the apparatus was left
stored in the old buildings. No
men will be sent north to witness
the total eclipse as Dean Ames
and Dr. Bliss say there is no scientific value to be derived from
Witnessing them other than that
which has already been obtained.

Contrary to custom, the 1925
"Hullabaloo" will not post its
group pictures for public inspection; it was decided at the last
board meeting, January 19. At the
same meeting a committee was
appointed for the purpose of taking separate, photographs of
seniors when each was in his favorite mood.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 23. 1925

Stanley Worden
Stars with
Playshop in
La liaison Natale
This is a difficult situation. We
want to
praise
highly the acting
and staging of the
Homewood Playshoppers' latest
production and yet we wish to
criticize the play itself. So in starting let us announce that we thoroughly enjoyed the aforesaid acting and staging. We only want to
bring out some weak spots in the
work of the Playshoppers wherever
We noticed them.
Jacques Copeau, Director, Le
Theatre du Vieux Colombier, Paris,
was associated many years with little theatres and their ideas before
he wrote La Maison Natale (The
Home into Which We Are Born),
yet this play hardly seems the type
best suited for little theatre actors.
The Homewood Playshop presented
it January 15, 16, 17, 20 and 21,
Which was the first time the production as translated by Ralph Roeder
was given in this country.
As best as we could discern the
action of the play seemed to revolve about a shrewd human—he
dies in the second intermission—
who .had underhandedly forced the
mayor of a small town to give him
his (laughter in marriage and his
factory, only to have his own children fear him and avoid his presence. The children especially the
Youngest son, prefer their now
broken old grandfather. This old
rascal, desiring revenge on his sonin-law, influences them to run away
from their father's oppression in
order to escape the fate of their
mother, and himself who have
cracked under the strain.
The acting of Stanley Worden
as the grandfather far surpassed
that of the rest. Mr. Worden is
still the most valuable man the
Playshoppers possess 'andlikewise
is the only one who retains his
character, whatever it may be, during the curtain calls.
The play itself seemed to us to
Portray its principal idea fairly
Well, though a bit morbidly: yet it
lacked a certain ease in the conversational speeches, many of which
were very long. This smoothness
may have been lost in the translat-

ing, which was evidently no masterpiece. The Playshoppers should
vary their type of plays a little
more and give lowbrows like ourselves a chance once in a while.
We did not think John Taylor
Myers quite lived up to his reputation of having once been in The
Miracle when he portrayed the
character of Andre, the idealistic
son. However we must admit his
was the most difficult role in the
performance.
G. H. Pouder in the part of the
harsh father evidently liked Clayton Hamilton's description of John
Barrymore's acting with his fingers
and eyebrows, for to our mind he
slightly overworked these parts of
his anatomy in giving vent to his
feelings. Mr. Pouder also seemed
to lose the value of a few lines and
often made his speeches while looking directly at the audience. Al-

though these lines may have had self contained possibilities with bet-- production was worthy of a much
to be delivered with the gaze fixed ter lines, the excellent cast deserved larger audience than turned out the
vacantly on some spot, they would a more fitting vehicle. Even so, the night we witnessed it. C. F. R.
have been more effective if Mr
Pouder had chosen a spot in greater proximity with the stage wall.
Milton E. Bond did some really
creditable acting in the small part
of Masure, a factory worker. Virginia Bowie, as the misunderstanding mother, and the less important
actors, while good, did not -quite
come up to the high standard set
by Mr. Worden.
Mr. Ponder must be given full
credit for directing the play. He
and the scene shifters are to be
highly praised for the short intermissions.
Baltimore's Best Store
Both scenes were well executed
and the lighting as excellent as usual. The make-ups, Mr. Worden's
in particular, were also faultless.

ART PRINTS AND
Painters, authors, and musicians win
fame and fortune by transmitting their
conceptions to paper. Achievement
can be completed merely with such
expression of an idea. Not so with
engineering. The design of a turbine
or of a flat iron, once it is created, is
not placed upon a pedestal in a millionaire's mansion,or in an art museum.
It immediately goes into the shop-there to be executed. Its success is
measured by the degree to which it
fits manufacturing requirements. If it
can't be manufactured economically

REGISTAR GIVES
CONSOLING FIGURES

it is a failure.

With examinations .only
some seventy hours distant
from the time this issue is
placed in the post office
boxes in the dim basement
of Gilman Hall, certain figures from the Registrar's Office come as a great comfort.

In an organization like Westinghouse there is a group of engineers
whose chief interest and concern is
the efficient, economical, large scale
manufacture of electrical products.
These men may be electrical engineers

Mr. Dempster announces,
with a click of his jaws, that
there are at present fortyeight on the blacklist, twenty-two of whom are on probation. As next week will
offer the large Freshman
class its first introduction to
this dubious honor roll, that
click seems to foretell an increase. Just as a ray of sunshine the Registrar points
out in parting that only
fifty-six out of every hundred
entering reach the rank of
Juniors..

or mechanical engineers. They are
primarily interested in shop practice
and methods—.--in the same industrial
problems as are the manufacturing
customers whom Westinghouse serves.
The founder of Westinghouse was
such an engineer. He possessed a marvelous faculty to inspire workmen and
executives alike; there are many tales
of men working nights and Sundays to
help him complete a cherished plan.
Throughout all industry there is a
call for men qualified as manufacturing
engineers who can combine materials,
machines, men, and methods with
better and more efficient results.
Such men find pleasure and inspiration at Westinghouse — developing
apparatus to help other manufacturing
executives solve similar problems in
every kind of industry.
